articles.headline: Fed Limits Bank Payouts and Suspends Share Buybacks as Pandemic Grinds On
articles.snippet: About a quarter of banks would near minimum capital levels in a double dip recession, the Fed said, as it announced its stress-test results.
articles.abstract: About a quarter of banks would near minimum capital levels in a double dip recession, the Fed said, as it announced its stress-test results.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve on Thursday temporarily restricted shareholder payouts by the nation’s biggest banks, barring them from buying back their own stocks or increasing dividend payments in the third quarter as regulators try to ensure banks remain strong enough to keep lending through the pandemic-induced downturn.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek, Peter Eavis and Kate Kelly

articles.headline: Still Reeling From Oil Plunge, Texas Faces New Threat: Surge in Virus Cases
articles.snippet: Businesses were reopening in recent weeks and oil prices had climbed north of $40 a barrel before coronavirus infections accelerated in the state.
articles.abstract: Businesses were reopening in recent weeks and oil prices had climbed north of $40 a barrel before coronavirus infections accelerated in the state.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Things were looking up for Texas in recent weeks. Oil prices had managed an impressive rebound, more than doubling to just above $40 a barrel. Restaurants and small businesses were opening up in Houston, Dallas and elsewhere. And tens of thousands of people were getting back to work.

articles.headline: Texas Pauses Reopening as Virus Cases Soar Across the South and West
articles.snippet: A growing number of states are pausing plans to reopen, amid rising case counts. But Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas said shutting back down was the “last thing we want to do.”
articles.abstract: A growing number of states are pausing plans to reopen, amid rising case counts. But Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas said shutting back down was the “last thing we want to do.”
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Just 55 days after reopening Texas restaurants and other businesses, Gov. Greg Abbott on Thursday hit the pause button, stopping additional phases of the state’s reopening as new coronavirus cases and hospitalizations soared and as the governor struggled to pull off the seemingly impossible task of keeping both the state open and the virus under control.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and Sarah Mervosh

articles.headline: Another Nightmare Video and the Police on the Defensive in Tucson
articles.snippet: A city with a relatively progressive image and reform-minded police is grappling with a brutal death in police custody — and why it took so long to become public.
articles.abstract: A city with a relatively progressive image and reform-minded police is grappling with a brutal death in police custody — and why it took so long to become public.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was another gruesome video of policing in America — a naked Latino man, his face covered by a mesh spit guard, his hands cuffed behind him as he lay dying face down on the ground at his grandmother’s house. He pleaded for water more than a dozen times, saying he could not breathe as police officers restrained his legs and torso.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero, Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

articles.headline: As Virus Surges, Younger People Account for ‘Disturbing’ Number of Cases
articles.snippet: People in their 20s, 30s and 40s account for a growing proportion of the cases in many places, raising fears that asymptomatic young people are helping to fuel the virus’s spread.
articles.abstract: People in their 20s, 30s and 40s account for a growing proportion of the cases in many places, raising fears that asymptomatic young people are helping to fuel the virus’s spread.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Younger people are making up a growing percentage of new coronavirus cases in cities and states where the virus is now surging, a trend that has alarmed public health officials and prompted renewed pleas for masks and social distancing.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Sarah Mervosh

articles.headline: Biden Is Getting a Lot of Advice on His V.P. Here’s What Voters Think.
articles.snippet: A large majority of voters say race should not be a factor in his decision, and none of the best-known candidates has emerged as a favorite.
articles.abstract: A large majority of voters say race should not be a factor in his decision, and none of the best-known candidates has emerged as a favorite.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our latest coverage of the Biden vs. Trump 2020 election here.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Katie Glueck

articles.headline: Many Latinos Couldn’t Stay Home. Now Virus Cases Are Soaring in Their Communities.
articles.snippet: Rates of coronavirus infection among Latinos have risen rapidly across the United States.
articles.abstract: Rates of coronavirus infection among Latinos have risen rapidly across the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Please sign up here to have the Race/Related newsletter delivered weekly to your inbox.]
articles.byline: By Shawn Hubler, Thomas Fuller, Anjali Singhvi and Juliette Love

articles.headline: Welcome to Applebee’s! Can I Get You Started With Some Disinfectant?
articles.snippet: Chain restaurants are rethinking food for diners who fear the virus — and one another.
articles.abstract: Chain restaurants are rethinking food for diners who fear the virus — and one another.
articles.lead_paragraph: Go right ahead and leave a cash tip for Debi Kane, a waitress at a TGI Fridays in Corona, Calif. She’ll appreciate the money, but there’s a catch. Under the company’s new pandemic-inspired rules, she will need to drop off those dollars in a back room, then head to a sink, take off her gloves and wash for 20 seconds. Then she’ll wipe her hands with paper towels and wave them in the air for a couple minutes, willing them to dry.

articles.headline: Starting Bonus for a Laundry Worker: How a Beach Town Wrestles With Jobless Benefits
articles.snippet: Rehoboth Beach, Del., provides insight into how a $600 expanded unemployment benefit is affecting rehiring.
articles.abstract: Rehoboth Beach, Del., provides insight into how a $600 expanded unemployment benefit is affecting rehiring.
articles.lead_paragraph: REHOBOTH BEACH, Del. — Kelsey McGarry went back to her job at Thompson Island Brewing Company in Rehoboth Beach, Del., in April even though doing so meant that she was earning less than she would have simply by accepting unemployment insurance, which included an extra $600 per week.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley
